message_1: Let X be a compact topological space and {U_n} be a sequence of open subsets of X such that U_1 contains U_2 contains U_3 and so on. If U_n is not equal to the empty set for all n, prove that the intersection of all U_n is not empty.
message_2:
To prove that the intersection of all U_n is not empty, we will use the concept of compactness. Recall that a topological space X is compact if every open cover of X has a finite subcover.

Consider the sequence of closed sets {C_n}, where C_n = X - U_n (the complement of U_n in X). Since U_n are open sets, C_n are closed sets. Moreover, C_n is an increasing sequence of closed sets, i.e., C_1 ⊆ C_2 ⊆ C_3 ⊆ ...

Now, let's assume that the intersection of all U_n is empty, i.e., ⋂ U_n = ∅. Then, the union of all C_n is equal to X, i.e., ⋃ C_n = X. Since X is compact, there exists a finite subcover of the open cover ⋃ C_n. Let's say this finite subcover is given by {C_n1, C_n2, ..., C_nk} where n1 < n2 < ... < nk.

Since C_n is an increasing sequence of closed sets, we have C_nk ⊇ C_n(k-1) ⊇ ... ⊇ C_n1. Therefore, C_nk is also a cover of X, i.e., X = C_nk. This implies that U_nk = X - C_nk = ∅, which contradicts our assumption that U_n is not equal to the empty set for all n.

Hence, our assumption that ⋂ U_n = ∅ is false, and the intersection of all U_n is not empty.
